overview: How does your identity shape the art and media you consume and create, and the cultures and subcultures you’re a part of? This subject will explore how young people engage with the arts (including visual arts, music and drama), and how this helps to form their cultural and social identities and develop and express individualities. This subject is taught in intensive mode with a combination of tutorials and a cultural site visit excursion. Students will participate in arts activities and create arts-based 'artefacts' to explore the links between the arts and youth identity. The subject supports students to understand the processes associated with art-making with young people, and develop essential skills such as leadership, collaboration, communication and personal and interpersonal expression. Students do not need existing experience in the practical arts.
ilo: Demonstrate understanding of contemporary social cultural theories regarding youth
Document a range of arts practices as art-makers and/or audience members
Apply arts making and responding skills to workplace situations
Research and analyse ways young people use the arts and technology/digital media when developing and expressing personal values, beliefs and personal identity
Research, critically reflect on and critique connections between young people and the Arts.
generic_skills: Communication and personal and interpersonal expression.

Inherent requirements (core participatio.content: Further details on how to seek academic adjustments can be found on the Student Equity and Disability Support website:http://services.unimelb.edu.au/student-equity/home

assessment.brief: Class presentation: Individual practical arts-based presentation (15 minutes)
Discussion Board Reports (3): comprising a 'street research' response (300 words); a critical response to one lecture (350 words); and an evaluation of one workshop (350 words).
assessment.timing: 2 Weeks after the end of teaching period
4 Weeks after the end of teaching period

assessment.hurdle: A minimum of 80% attendance at, or engagement with, all sessions identified as contact hours (may include lectures, tutorials, seminars and workshops, both synchronous and asynchronous).

date_times.contact_hours: 36 hours (30 hours of on campus classes and 6 hours of asynchronous activities)
